contentlets.description:
Enabling Skills 1 introduces students to fundamental skills of studying at university. The course is taught in an interactive method, so that students are able to learn through participation. The course contains a number of written and spoken assignments which allow students to develop their reading, writing, thinking, researching and spoken skills. These assignments are based around essay writing and critical and reflective thinking. Considerable feedback is offered on each assignment. The course will be based around a general topic: the role of technology.

This course is for Indigenous students completing the Humanities Pathway Program 7016.

Enabling Skills 2 develops the fundamental skills of studying at university. It builds on skills already learned in Enabling Skills 1, but introduces students to study strategies used broadly in social science. The course is taught in an interactive method, so that students are able to learn through participation. The course contains a number of written and spoken assignments which allow students to further deepen their reading, writing, thinking, researching and spoken skills. These assignments include report writing, critically reviewing material, gathering and analysis of data, and organising data into an archive. Similar to term one, this course will be based around the general topic of technology.


This course is for Indigenous students completing the Humanities Pathway Program 7016.

contentlets.description:
Enabling Skills 2 develops the fundamental skills of studying at university. It builds on skills already learned in Enabling Skills 1, but introduces students to study strategies used broadly in social science. The course is taught in an interactive method, so that students are able to learn through participation. The course contains a number of written and spoken assignments which allow students to further deepen their reading, writing, thinking, researching and spoken skills. These assignments include report writing, critically reviewing material, gathering and analysis of data, and organising data into an archive. Similar to term one, this course will be based around the general topic of technology.

This course is for Indigenous students completing the Humanities Pathway Program 7016.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ATSI1011 - Indigenous Australia","description":"

Indigenous Australia is the gateway course to the Indigenous Studies Major. In this course students will gain an understanding of the diversity of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultures, peoples and societies. A central focus of the course is the ways in which the philosophical frameworks of Indigenous knowledge systems continue to inform contemporary Indigenous practice that continues to shape Indigenous identities today. Taught from a range of perspectives, students will develop an understanding of social, cultural, political, economic, and ecological aspects of Indigenous Knowledge, which are key foundational elements to the Indigenous Studies Major.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ATSI1012 - Aboriginal Sydney","description":"

In this course students are introduced to Aboriginal Sydney through local written and oral histories, as well as notable works in film, performance, television and art, seeking to make visible Aboriginal experiences, lives and connections to place in the city. Different approaches to urban history and to understanding the relationship between identity, memory and place are discussed against the broader context of imperial and colonial history and the marginalisation of Aboriginal land and heritage. With a specific focus on doing place-specific research, students are encouraged to get outside of the classroom and visit the places they are learning about. 



","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"79d7d8d7db25f450be4672f5f3961908","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Quiz","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

The task is designed to encourage early engagement with and feedback on learning, as well as understanding of course concepts. Feedback on quiz answers will be given in tutorials.

contentlets.description: In this course students are introduced to Aboriginal Sydney through local written and oral histories, as well as notable works in film, performance, television and art, seeking to make visible Aboriginal experiences, lives and connections to place in the city. Different approaches to urban history and to understanding the relationship between identity, memory and place are discussed against the broader context of imperial and colonial history and the marginalisation of Aboriginal land and heritage. With a specific focus on doing place-specific research, students are encouraged to get outside of the classroom and visit the places they are learning about.
contentlets.title: Aboriginal Sydney

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ATSI2003 - Indigenous Material Culture-Objects and Their Journey","description":"

The focus of this course is on the role of museums and art galleries in the representation of Indigenous peoples and their cultures. The course begins with an introduction to Indigenous material culture, in both pre-contact and contact Australia. Students will also learn about the collection, study and display of Indigenous objects by museums and galleries. In this context disciplines of anthropology, ethnography, archaeology and museology are examined. Particular attention is given to the ways in which we can study objects and their different meanings as they journey from Indigenous contexts to non-Indigenous institutions. Students undertake an excursion to one or more local museums and participate in interactive seminar discussion as part of this course.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"d7d75cd7db25f450be4672f5f396191d","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Object biography","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Drawing on the theoretical concepts and ideas presented in the course, students are required to carefully interpret and study an Indigenous object that they have learned about during a museum excursion in an essay (2000 words) that must also draw on additional research.

Students will receive comprehensive written feedback and essays will be marked according to established marking criteria that are made available to students at the beginning of term.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d7d75cd7db25f450be4672f5f396191e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"d7d75cd7db25f450be4672f5f396191f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"d7d75cd7db25f450be4672f5f3961920","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"dfd75cd7db25f450be4672f5f396191f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1fd75cd7db25f450be4672f5f3961937","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

Each week students will be required to read assigned material so they can contribute effectively to class discussions. Discussion questions or topics for debate will be presented to students throughout the term, and verbal and written answers will be sought from students during tutorial sessions.

Participation will be marked according to established marking criteria that are made available to students at the beginning of term.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"dfd75cd7db25f450be4672f5f396191d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"dfd75cd7db25f450be4672f5f396191f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9fd75cd7db25f450be4672f5f3961921","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Exhibition interpretation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

Students are required to give a 10 minute group presentation (20%) that critically evaluates a museum or gallery exhibition that represents Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander peoples and their cultures and/or histories. Students are also required to submit a written review (1000 words, 30 %) a week after their presentation incorporating relevant research and feedback provided in class.

Presentations and reviews are marked according to established marking criteria that are made available to students at the beginning of term.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ATSI2004 - Popular Culture of Indigenous Australia","description":"

Representations and misrepresentations of Australian Indigeneity as part of the national identity are most often portrayed through forms of popular culture. Popular Culture of Indigenous Australia will focus on the participation of Indigenous people in these fields and how that involvement influences national identities. The course will explore the complexities of Indigenous identities and the nuances in the way these identities are expressed. Students are encouraged to reflect on Indigenous place and space as part of their own identities and further reflect on the place of indigeneity in the national consciousness.

Drawing on the theoretical concepts and ideas presented in the course, students are required to write a small series of brief scholarly reviews of Indigenous Australian popular culture.

contentlets.description: Representations and misrepresentations of Australian Indigeneity as part of the national identity are most often portrayed through forms of popular culture. Popular Culture of Indigenous Australia will focus on the participation of Indigenous people in these fields and how that involvement influences national identities. The course will explore the complexities of Indigenous identities and the nuances in the way these identities are expressed. Students are encouraged to reflect on Indigenous place and space as part of their own identities and further reflect on the place of indigeneity in the national consciousness.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ATSI2011 - Indigenous Australian Political History","description":"

Indigenous Australian Political History tells the story of Indigenous resistance, activism and political organisation during the twentieth century in Australia. Each week focuses on the story of a particular Indigenous leader, with emphasis on the historical contexts and political environments that shaped their perspectives and actions. Brought together, the course forms a narrative revealing the recurring themes, directions, tensions, successes and legacies of Indigenous political history.

Students are required to respond to weekly course readings and guide the class through a discussion of the salient points. Students are marked according to established criteria made available at the beginning of term and they are also given written feedback.

Over a period of nine weeks, students will be given specific roles to guide their engagement with course readings and to structure their participation in tutorial discussion. Students will post the content of their weekly on Moodle. After receiving oral feedback in class, and talking through their ideas with their peers, they select two posts to edit and submit for formal grading. Students will receive comprehensive written feedback on graded posts and they will be marked according to established marking criteria made available to students at the beginning of term.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"82e7101bdb25f450be4672f5f39619ee","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"82e7101bdb25f450be4672f5f39619ef","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8ae7101bdb25f450be4672f5f39619ee","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9ee7101bdb25f450be4672f5f39619f8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Students are required to submit an essay demonstrating independent research made in response to an essay question specified by the course coordinator. The essay will be graded according to marking criteria made available to students at the beginning of term and returned to students with written feedback.

contentlets.keywords: nura gili (indigenous programs),indigenous,aboriginal peoples,torres strait islander peoples,australia,colonisation,indigenous knowledge,history,politics
contentlets.description: Indigenous Australian Political History tells the story of Indigenous resistance, activism and political organisation during the twentieth century in Australia. Each week focuses on the story of a particular Indigenous leader, with emphasis on the historical contexts and political environments that shaped their perspectives and actions. Brought together, the course forms a narrative revealing the recurring themes, directions, tensions, successes and legacies of Indigenous political history.
contentlets.title: Indigenous Australian Political History

Contemporary Issues in Indigenous Politics","description":"

Contemporary Issues in Indigenous Politics examines contemporary debates in Australian Indigenous affairs, placing an emphasis on the political contexts within which these debates take place. Students will learn to analyse political debates in Indigenous affairs in terms of the history of state strategies to transform Indigenous populations and Indigenous peoples' strategies to retain control over their collective cultural, political and economic development. The course encourages students to consider the impact of powerful interests, ideology and political institutions in constraining and enabling political participation by Indigenous people and communities. It also explores different models of political representation and engagement in the context of contemporary debates around recognition, sovereignty and treaty.

Drawing on the theoretical concepts and ideas presented in the course, students are required to carefully interpret and critically analyse information before responding to an essay question and formulating their own ideas in the form of a written essay. Students will receive comprehensive written feedback and essays will be marked according to established marking criteria that are made available to students at the beginning of term.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b3e7901bdb25f450be4672f5f39619eb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b3e7901bdb25f450be4672f5f39619ec","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"bbe7901bdb25f450be4672f5f39619ea","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"bbe7901bdb25f450be4672f5f39619eb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"bbe7901bdb25f450be4672f5f39619ec","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"73e7901bdb25f450be4672f5f39619fb","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Short responses","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Students are required to submit short one-paragraph responses to set questions every fortnight during the term. The responses will relate to the course readings and materials covered in class over the previous fortnight. The word limit for each response is 200 words, and students will submit a total of 5 responses over the term. These responses will be graded according to criteria made available to students at the beginning of term.

Students will write an informed opinion piece on one political issue in Indigenous affairs. Students will receive comprehensive written feedback and papers will be marked according to established marking criteria that are made available to students at the beginning of term.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ATSI2014 - Indigenous People and Policy","description":"

This course aims to develop student understanding of the role of public policy in shaping Indigenous communities. It considers case studies of policy development by Australian Commonwealth, State and Territory authorities. It provides students with a theoretical framework for understanding policy and policy development processes and observing how key actors and institutions shape policy outcomes. The course considers opportunities for participation and engagement in policy formulation, and reflects on past policies which have contributed to Indigenous disadvantage and marginalisation. Students will critically analyse past and current policies and develop their understanding of the important role that policy plays in shaping community.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"91f7541bdb25f450be4672f5f3961913","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Students are required to answer a set essay question with a word limit of 2500 words. The essay provides students with an opportunity to synthesise the content of seminars, set readings and independent research into a cohesive structured body of work.
Essays will be marked according to established marking criteria which are made available to students at the beginning of semester. Students will receive written feedback within 2 weeks of submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"91f7541bdb25f450be4672f5f3961914","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"99f7541bdb25f450be4672f5f3961913","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"99f7541bdb25f450be4672f5f3961914","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"99f7541bdb25f450be4672f5f3961915","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"29f7541bdb25f450be4672f5f3961920","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Students are required to work in groups to develop and deliver a 20 minute presentation on a past policy that has impacted an Indigenous community, or Indigenous communities more generally. Students will be expected to submit a written version of their presentation on the same day.
Presentations are marked according to established marking criteria that are made available to students at the beginning of semester. Students are provided with written feedback within 2 weeks of submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"91f7541bdb25f450be4672f5f3961915","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"99f7541bdb25f450be4672f5f3961914","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"99f7541bdb25f450be4672f5f3961915","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"51f7541bdb25f450be4672f5f3961917","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Policy brief","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Students are required to prepare a policy brief for the relevant government minister about a policy issue which has impacted Indigenous communities. The policy brief should be no longer than 1000 words, and should provide a coherent argument, relevant background material, and a set of clear policy recommendations. Students should draw on course content related to the policy process, competing problem definitions, and key actors and institutions involved in making policy for Indigenous people and communities, and they should engage critically with a range of viewpoints in the public debate in their chosen policy area.

\n

The marking criteria for the policy brief will be provided at the beginning of semester, and students will receive written feedback within 2 weeks of submission through Moodle.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"91f7541bdb25f450be4672f5f3961914","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"99f7541bdb25f450be4672f5f3961913","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"99f7541bdb25f450be4672f5f3961915","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5df7541bdb25f450be4672f5f396191b","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/ATSI2014.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ATSI2015 - The Science of Indigenous Knowledges","description":"

In this course students will explore the history, philosophy, theory, and methods of Western science and ethnoscience. Students will critique the development, application, and dissemination of traditional Indigenous knowledge about the natural world, including astronomy, weather, medicine, geography, and mathematics. ATSI2015 Science of Indigenous Knowledge provides a framework for students to explore the history and development of science in both Western and Indigenous contexts by learning how knowledge systems are developed and how this knowledge is passed down to successive generations through oral tradition and material culture. Students learn about the history of colonial "scientific" practices that disempowered Indigenous people and led to environmental damage and unsustainable practices. Students will discover ways in which Indigenous Knowledge can inform and benefit Western science, and investigate how scientists and Indigenous communities are now collaborating to provide new technologies and developing sustainable practices that are beneficial to all. Students will use the tools they learn to benefit their careers and practices to move toward a sustainable and mutually beneficial future.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"fef7941bdb25f450be4672f5f39619f4","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

Each week students will be required to read the appropriate material so they can contribute effectively to class discussions. Discussion questions or topics for debate will be presented to students throughout the term, and verbal and written answers will be sought from students during tutorial sessions.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"bef7941bdb25f450be4672f5f39619f6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"03f7d41bdb25f450be4672f5f3961903","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group Investigation and Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will work in groups of three to investigate the relationship or connections between Indigenous knowledges and science by exploring how scientific knowledge is encoded in Indigenous cultural beliefs, objects or practices. Their findings will be documented in a 3 minute movie/iMovie and shown to the class as part of a 20 minute presentation that elaborates on their findings and their research process.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"bef7941bdb25f450be4672f5f39619f5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"bef7941bdb25f450be4672f5f39619f6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0bf7941bdb25f450be4672f5f39619ff","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reflective Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

Students will reflect on what they are learning about the science of indigenous knowledges and consider whether or how the content is relatable to their own area of study. Students will consider how their own discipline would perceive indigenous knowledge systems, whether there would be contention or openness to indigenous knowledge and how their own learning can be informed by indigenous knowledges.

The paper will be graded according to established marking criteria that are made available to students a the beginning of term.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b6f7941bdb25f450be4672f5f39619f6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"bef7941bdb25f450be4672f5f39619f6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"76f7941bdb25f450be4672f5f39619f8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"35","description":"

Students will research and write a 2000 word essay on any aspect of the course that demonstrates  contested or collaborative engagements between Western scientific and indigenous approaches to the construction, explanations and uses of knowledge systems.

The essay will be graded according to established marking criteria that are made available to students a the beginning of term.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"bef7941bdb25f450be4672f5f39619f5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"bef7941bdb25f450be4672f5f39619f6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"fef7941bdb25f450be4672f5f39619fb","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/ATSI2015.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ATSI3002 - Gendered Identities in Indigenous Australia","description":"

The course explores the way in which gender influences and structures the experiences of Indigenous women and men in the past and the present. It encourages students to engage in critical analysis and discussions by presenting relevant examples of the way in which gender and Indigeneity intersect in different contexts. The course material covers a range of issues involving gender and gender roles, including land, art and popular culture, activism, feminism, violence, and race. Particular attention is paid to colonial constructs of gender and gender roles within Aboriginal communities and Aboriginal women's and men's roles in subverting the colonisation of their identities.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"1808181bdb25f450be4672f5f39619c8","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seminar Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

In their presentations, students identify and critically analyse an example from popular culture (art, film, music, advertising, social media etc) using theories of gender, race and indigeneity. Students will be expected to draw on course readings and additional research, and demonstrate how this research has shaped their interpretation of the chosen example. This task is designed to encourage deeper engagement with ideas of gender, race and identity and their relevance in Indigenous contexts.

Presentation is marked according to criteria made available to the students at the beginning of semester.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1008181bdb25f450be4672f5f39619ca","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1008181bdb25f450be4672f5f39619cb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"1808181bdb25f450be4672f5f39619c9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"1808181bdb25f450be4672f5f39619cb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1408181bdb25f450be4672f5f39619da","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

The research essay (2500 words) allows students to synthesise course content and demonstrate understanding of various theories, concepts and ideas presented throughout the semester by responding to an essay question made available on Moodle. Students may also propose their own essay question if they wish. Students are expected to undertake substantial independent research for this assessment task.

Students will be provided with the marking rubric and they will receive written feedback on the assessment task via Moodle.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1008181bdb25f450be4672f5f39619c9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1008181bdb25f450be4672f5f39619cb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"1808181bdb25f450be4672f5f39619c9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1808181bdb25f450be4672f5f39619ca","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"1808181bdb25f450be4672f5f39619cb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1808181bdb25f450be4672f5f39619d3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Online journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will contribute to an online journal of the weekly readings, responding to specific questions and each other's responses. The total word limit of the assessment is 1000 words (approximately 100-200 words per week).

Students will receive individual midterm feedback on their online journal entries. The entries will be marked according criteria made available to students at the beginning of semester.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ATSI3003 - Indigenous Cultural Heritage and the Environment","description":"

This course explores Indigenous perspectives on the management of country, waterways, culture and heritage in Australia. By exploring intersections between cultural heritage management practices, the environment, Indigenous knowledges and the contemporary space, students will gain an insight into best practice models for cultural heritage management and associated practices of sustainability and maintenance of Australia's rich cultural heritage and the environment. A compulsory field trip for this course incurs an additional cost.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"4608d81bdb25f450be4672f5f396197b","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"Drawing on the theoretical concepts and ideas presented in the seminars and field-trip, students are required to interpret and critically analyse information by responding to an essay question. They should formulate their own ideas in the form of a written essay.
Students will receive written feedback and essays will be marked according to established marking criteria that are made available to students at the beginning of semester.","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4608d81bdb25f450be4672f5f396197c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"4608d81bdb25f450be4672f5f396197d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"4e08d81bdb25f450be4672f5f396197d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5208d81bdb25f450be4672f5f3961989","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Attendance and Participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Attendance","value":"attendance"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

The field trip component of the course is integral to the development of student knowledge and understanding of Indigenous knowledge on country, how Indigenous peoples navigate the everyday, and how they continue to experience the ongoing issues associated with colonisation. Students will have the opportunity to engage in depth discussions with Aboriginal community members of the Yuin Nation, who will provide a Welcome to Country and guided tours of various sites of significance to the local Aboriginal community. Whilst attendance on the field trip is compulsory, participation will be assessed on students' level of engagement in the activities during the field trip and seminars.     

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4608d81bdb25f450be4672f5f396197c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4e08d81bdb25f450be4672f5f396197b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"4e08d81bdb25f450be4672f5f396197c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9a08d81bdb25f450be4672f5f396198d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Annotation Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"25","description":"

The Annotation Report is well suited to the delivery of ATSI3003 which consists of 4 x 3 hour seminars and a three day field trip to an Aboriginal community. The assessment is completed in two parts. Part one consists of weekly annotations over the course of five consecutive weeks. Each week (i.e. weeks 2-6) students must submit an annotation of a prescribed article of no more than one A4 page in length. The required structure of the annotation will be communicated to students in the Course Outline, on the ATSI3003 Moodle page, via email, and during the feedback process. Part two is the final report which is due in week 7 or 8 and must include the five annotations attached as an appendix.

\n

Students will receive weekly feedback on their annotation assessments. The more work needed on each annotation to bring them up to the standard required, the more detailed feedback the student will receive. It is therefore possible that a student may receive considerable feedback on the first annotation, but receive limited feedback on subsequent annotations. No mark or grade will be given to individual annotations, rather the final Annotation Report will be assessed in its entirety against a marking criteria, and a final mark given. Students are encouraged to incorporate any prior feedback into their final Annotation Reports.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"4608d81bdb25f450be4672f5f396197d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4e08d81bdb25f450be4672f5f396197b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"4e08d81bdb25f450be4672f5f396197d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"d608d81bdb25f450be4672f5f3961984","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"Students are required to develop and deliver a presentation on an aspect of cultural heritage management practices experienced on the field-trip. This is a group exercise which is to be delivered in small groups of two or three. The topic for the presentation will be negotiated between group members. Possible topics include the role of Indigenous knowledges in cultural heritage management, traditional owners as caretakers of country and impacts of non-Indigenous settlement on site.
Presentations are marked according to established marking criteria that are made available to students at the beginning of semester. The marking and feedback process is aided by the submission of fully reference presentation notes which will be presented back to the students with written feedback.","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4608d81bdb25f450be4672f5f396197c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"4608d81bdb25f450be4672f5f396197d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"4e08d81bdb25f450be4672f5f396197d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"da08d81bdb25f450be4672f5f396197f","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/ATSI3003.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ATSI3005 - Race, Colonialism and Whiteness","description":"

There are (at least) two sides to the colonial relationship. In this class we focus on the ways in which colonialism is enmeshed with White knowledge traditions and cultures so that we can better understand the complex relationship between Indigenous and non-Indigenous Australia. Students will be introduced to key concepts and thinkers in the fields of Critical Race and Whiteness theory and together we will apply them to everyday experience and popular culture. At the theory and application learning stage of the Indigenous Studies Major, this course will help students develop their understanding of identity politics that are deeply entangled with a variety of political and intellectual debates in Australia.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"fc18dc1bdb25f450be4672f5f396195b","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seminar Discussion Leadership","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Students are given the opportunity to develop their skills as course tutors with supervision and support from the course coordinator. From week two onward, each seminar discussion will be lead by a small group of students, to be scheduled in week one. The discussion leaders' role is to facilitate a sensible engagement with the core texts and the topic for that week. This is not a presentation and students are not required to prepare a summary of the core texts. Students may approach this assessment in a variety of ways. This might involve preparing activities, gathering examples from outside of class, organising a debate or something else.

Discussion leaders are also required to submit a one page summary of their planned discussion points and/or activities before the seminar. Students receive written feedback within a week.

Discussion leadership is marked according to criteria made available to students at the beginning of term.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"bc18dc1bdb25f450be4672f5f396195c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"bc18dc1bdb25f450be4672f5f396195e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3018dc1bdb25f450be4672f5f3961968","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

Drawing on the theoretical concepts and ideas presented in the course, students are required to write an essay in response to one of a range of set questions, or a question of their own design developed in consulation with the course coordinator.


Students are given comprehensive written feedback and are marked according to criteria made available to at the beginning of term.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"b418dc1bdb25f450be4672f5f396195d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3818dc1bdb25f450be4672f5f3961965","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Critical Reflective Journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Students are required to submit journal entries online between weeks two and nine. Journals must draw comparisons and connections between the set texts, and between the texts, the course and students' own experience, prior leaning, and assumptions.

Colated journal entries are submitted for feedback twice during term. Submissions are given written feedback and are marked according to criteria made available to students at the beginning of term.

Students will be introduced to key concepts and thinkers in the fields of Critical Race and Whiteness theory and together we will apply them to everyday experience and popular culture. At the theory and application learning stage of the Indigenous Studies Major, this course will help students develop their understanding of identity politics that are deeply entangled with a variety of political and intellectual debates in Australia.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ATSI3008 - Indigenous Studies Capstone","description":"

This is the Capstone course for students completing the Indigenous Studies Major. The course draws on content, themes and theories from all levels of the Indigenous Studies Major to consolidate understandings of the convergences that characterise the relations between Indigenous and non-Indigenous Australia. Students in this course will learn how to explore the deeper complexities of their chosen disciplines and Indigenous Australia, and practise ways to productively engage their boundaries, limits and agendas. Students will have the opportunity to refine their analytical and communicative capacities to navigate these boundaries as their preparation for professional practice or further study.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"8218505bdb25f450be4672f5f3961923","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Essay Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Students are required to submit a proposal for a research essay that explains their research motivation and the topic significance alongside an annotated bibliography demonstrating their engagement with independently searched literature relevant to their research area. The assessment will be graded according to marking criteria made available to students at the beginning of term. Each student will be given detailed written feedback.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c618505bdb25f450be4672f5f3961924","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ce18505bdb25f450be4672f5f3961923","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ce18505bdb25f450be4672f5f3961924","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ce18505bdb25f450be4672f5f3961925","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1e18505bdb25f450be4672f5f3961930","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Students are required to submit a research essay based on a research topic and question developed over the course of the capstone in consultation with the course coordinator. The assessment will be graded according to marking criteria made available to students at the beginning of the term. Each student will be given detailed written feedback. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"c618505bdb25f450be4672f5f3961925","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ce18505bdb25f450be4672f5f3961923","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ce18505bdb25f450be4672f5f3961925","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8218505bdb25f450be4672f5f396192c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

In class, students will be required to present on their research question, initial findings from a literature search, and key evidence informing their final research essay. The assessment will be graded according to marking criteria made available to students at the beginning of term. Informal feedback and direction will be given at the end of each presentation. In addition each student will be given specific written feedback related to their grade.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ATSI3017 - Indigenous Histories and the Colonial World","description":"

This course explores Australia's Indigenous histories and their contemporary resonance. It offers students an overview of relationships between settlers and Indigenous peoples, focusing on contact zones and tracing some of the ways Indigenous people have made their own histories in varied contexts of violence and settler colonialism. The course material will cover nineteenth century Indigenous travellers and Indigenous judicial proceedings, examine violence and friendship, study reserves and resistance, and historicise displacement and the many novel articulations of land rights. Students will engage with controversies attached to representing Indigenous histories in the present, and complete in-depth and independent historical research.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"3a18505bdb25f450be4672f5f39619fd","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Reflective/Critical Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will critically reflect on different ways of representing Indigenous pasts, and write a 1000 word essay assessing the way these approaches to history can illuminate various aspects of Indigenous experience in the colonial world.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f618505bdb25f450be4672f5f39619fe","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f618505bdb25f450be4672f5f39619ff","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"fe18505bdb25f450be4672f5f39619fe","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"fe18505bdb25f450be4672f5f39619ff","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8718905bdb25f450be4672f5f396190c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Research Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Students will draw on a range of primary sources to write a 3000 word essay demonstrating their ability to synthesise, interpret, and analyse information. The essay questions will invite students to explore aspects of Indigenous history and produce a sensitive and complex account of Indigenous Australian pasts.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f618505bdb25f450be4672f5f39619ff","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f618905bdb25f450be4672f5f3961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"fe18505bdb25f450be4672f5f39619fe","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"fe18505bdb25f450be4672f5f39619ff","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8b18905bdb25f450be4672f5f3961906","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Blogging Exercise","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will contribute to an online discussion of the weekly readings, responding to specific questions and to each others' responses. The total word length of the assessment is 1000 words (approximately 100-200 words per week).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f618505bdb25f450be4672f5f39619fe","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f618905bdb25f450be4672f5f3961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"fe18505bdb25f450be4672f5f39619fe","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"be18905bdb25f450be4672f5f3961901","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/ATSI3017.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.description: This course explores Australia's Indigenous histories and their contemporary resonance. It offers students an overview of relationships between settlers and Indigenous peoples, focusing on contact zones and tracing some of the ways Indigenous people have made their own histories in varied contexts of violence and settler colonialism. The course material will cover nineteenth century Indigenous travellers and Indigenous judicial proceedings, examine violence and friendship, study reserves and resistance, and historicise displacement and the many novel articulations of land rights. Students will engage with controversies attached to representing Indigenous histories in the present, and complete in-depth and independent historical research.
contentlets.title: Indigenous Histories and the Colonial World

The course is designed to build on and extend knowledge of Indigenous Studies developed over an undergraduate degree. The course will engage critically with current theoretical and conceptual debates and will introduce students to key international and Australian authors in the discipline. The course is designed to develop critical thinking and analytical skills in preparation for thesis work, and to help students to position their own research within the discipline of Indigenous Studies.

This task is a research essay which draws on course readings alongside substantial independent research. The word limit is 3000 words. Students will develop their own research essay question in consultation with the course convenor, and will have regular opportunities to discuss their progress and seek guidance from the convenor.

Students will be provided with the marking criteria at the start of the semester, and will receive written feedback via Moodle within two weeks of submission.

Annotations of readings will be submitted electronically each fortnight during the semester, resulting in a total of six separate submissions, each with a word limit of 300 words. Marking criteria for the annotations will be provided at the start of the course, and students will receive written feedback on their work from the course convenor via Moodle.

Students will be required to deliver a short presentation of 10 to 15 minutes in one of the weekly seminars. This presentation will engage with the weekly readings, identify key areas of contention in the scholarly debate, and raise substantial questions for group discussion. Students will be expected to submit their written notes for the presentation on the same day.

Students will be provided with the marking criteria for the presentation at the start of semester, and will receive written feedback the following week.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ATSI4003 - Research Design in Indigenous Studies","description":"

This course is a core component of the Honours year in Indigenous Studies. It includes an intensive workshop on research design and methodology at the start of the academic year, and regular workshops through terms 1 and 2 which will develop skills in research, analytical and writing.The course as a whole is designed to prepare students for designing and carrying out an Honours thesis project in Indigenous Studies. Students will be exposed to research methods and practices in the field in the context of approaches in the social sciences and humanities. They will have the opportunity to discuss and explore some of the major contemporary approaches to Indigenous Studies and some of the key issues raised by academic research and writing in the field, including ethical implications of research. Students will be well prepared to complete an Honours thesis, and will have the necessary basis for further research.


Note: This is a 12 UOC course. You will enrol in 6 UOC in each of two successive terms with a result reported by a single grade at the end of the second 6 UOC course.

Students will be asked to present the key elements of their research proposal and plan of action to the class in an engaging oral and visual presentation.

The marking criteria for the presentation will be provided to students at the start of the semester. Students will receive feedback on their presentation via Moodle within two weeks of the presentation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"d528145bdb25f450be4672f5f39619e5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"dd28145bdb25f450be4672f5f39619e5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"dd28145bdb25f450be4672f5f39619e6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2128545bdb25f450be4672f5f3961902","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Writing tasks","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will be given four specific writing tasks at each of the workshops and will be required to submit each task one week after the workshop. Each task will be equally weighted towards the 20% of the final grade for the course. The tasks will be designed to develop skills in research, analysis and writing. 

Marking criteria for the tasks will be provided and discussed at each workshop. Students will receive written feedback on their work via Moodle within one week of submission of each task.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"dd28145bdb25f450be4672f5f39619e6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6928545bdb25f450be4672f5f3961906","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Thesis proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will be asked to produce a substantial research proposal that presents a clearly articulated contribution to the literature, a plan for producing that contribution, and a reflection on the feasibility of the research project. The word limit for the research proposal is 4000 words. This assessment task is designed to allow students to demonstrate a critical knowledge of research design and methodology derived from the intensive module. The proposal will address a topic developed in consultation with the Honours Coordinator and their supervisor.

Students will have opportunities to discuss their work before submission with the Honours Coordinator and/or their supervisor. Marking criteria for the research proposal will be provided at the start of semester. Students will receive feedback on their proposal via Moodle within two weeks of submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"d528145bdb25f450be4672f5f39619e5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d528145bdb25f450be4672f5f39619e7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"dd28145bdb25f450be4672f5f39619e4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"dd28145bdb25f450be4672f5f39619e5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"dd28145bdb25f450be4672f5f39619e6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9d28145bdb25f450be4672f5f39619e8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Literature Review","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

The literature review task involves mapping the field of literature which is relevant to the student's chosen thesis topic. This task requires students to research independently and widely, and to demonstrate a thorough knowledge of the field as well as an ability to identify major debates, key figures and writers, and germinal texts appropriate to their chosen topic. The word limit for the literature review is 3000 words.

The marking criteria for the literature review will be provided at the start of the course. Students will have opportunities to discuss their work before submission with the Honours Coordinator and/or their thesis supervisor. Feedback will be provided via Moodle within two weeks of submission of the literature review.

contentlets.description:
This course is a core component of the Honours year in Indigenous Studies. It includes an intensive workshop on research design and methodology at the start of the academic year, and regular workshops through terms 1 and 2 which will develop skills in research, analytical and writing.The course as a whole is designed to prepare students for designing and carrying out an Honours thesis project in Indigenous Studies. Students will be exposed to research methods and practices in the field in the context of approaches in the social sciences and humanities. They will have the opportunity to discuss and explore some of the major contemporary approaches to Indigenous Studies and some of the key issues raised by academic research and writing in the field, including ethical implications of research. Students will be well prepared to complete an Honours thesis, and will have the necessary basis for further research.

Note: This is a 12 UOC course. You will enrol in 6 UOC in each of two successive terms with a result reported by a single grade at the end of the second 6 UOC course.

Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ATSI7001 - Pre-Business Program (Indigenous)","description":"

The Indigenous Pre-Business course is an intensive four-week residential course for prospective Indigenous students wanting to enrol in an undergraduate degree in the Australian Business School at UNSW. The course has been designed to assess your academic potential and to provide a realistic environment within which you can develop the knowledge and skills to manage your undergraduate studies effectively.


The Pre-Business course will engage you in learning activities associated with the following business disciplines: Accounting; Business Finance; Business Law; People and Organisational Management; Economics; Information Systems and Marketing.  There is a strong focus on the acquisition of the study and learning skills required to undertake Business studies at the university level. Students are also given opportunities to apply their learning through case studies, written and oral presentations and site visits.


Entry into the Indigenous Pre-Business course is based on a completed application form and an interview with staff from Nura Gili and the Australian School of Business. On successful completion of the course, measured through participation, assessments and a final interview, students may then be offered a place in a Business degree at UNSW. For further information please contact Nura Gili at UNSW.

Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ATSI7002 - Pre-Law Program (Indigenous)","description":"

The Indigenous Pre-Law course is an intensive four-week residential course for prospective Indigenous students wanting to enrol in an undergraduate degree in Law at UNSW. The course has been designed to assess your academic potential and to provide a realistic environment within which you can develop the knowledge and skills to manage your undergraduate studies effectively.


The course focuses on teaching students a broad range of academic and legal skills, and legal knowledge. Skills include critical thinking, reading, writing and speaking in both a legal and general academic context so that students are well prepared to undertake tertiary studies. The course is also directed at ensuring that students are equipped with foundational knowledge about the Australian legal system that will support their learning in first year law courses.


Entry into the Indigenous Pre-Law course is based on a completed application form and lodgement of supporting documentation, which is then assessed by Nura Gili and Faculty staff. On occasion, applicants may be required to attend an interview as part of this assessment process. On successful completion of the course, measured through participation, assessments and a final interview, students may then be offered a place in a Law degree at UNSW. For further information please contact Nura Gili at UNSW.

contentlets.description:
The Indigenous Pre-Law course is an intensive four-week residential course for prospective Indigenous students wanting to enrol in an undergraduate degree in Law at UNSW. The course has been designed to assess your academic potential and to provide a realistic environment within which you can develop the knowledge and skills to manage your undergraduate studies effectively.

The course focuses on teaching students a broad range of academic and legal skills, and legal knowledge. Skills include critical thinking, reading, writing and speaking in both a legal and general academic context so that students are well prepared to undertake tertiary studies. The course is also directed at ensuring that students are equipped with foundational knowledge about the Australian legal system that will support their learning in first year law courses.

Entry into the Indigenous Pre-Law course is based on a completed application form and lodgement of supporting documentation, which is then assessed by Nura Gili and Faculty staff. On occasion, applicants may be required to attend an interview as part of this assessment process. On successful completion of the course, measured through participation, assessments and a final interview, students may then be offered a place in a Law degree at UNSW. For further information please contact Nura Gili at UNSW.
contentlets.title: Pre-Law Program (Indigenous)

The PMP is an intensive academic program that runs for four weeks at the University of New South Wales in Sydney.  The topics covered during the program will introduce you to some of the content covered in first year Medicine, and further develop your academic skills to enable you to more effectively engage with this content.


The program focuses on two broad topic areas in Basic and Clinical Sciences and Academic Skills.  Students are introduced to the Basic and Clinical Sciences covered in first year medicine.  These will include:


  • Anatomy
  • Biochemistry
  • Biology
  • Ethics
  • Histology
  • Microbiology
  • Pathology
  • Pharmacology
  • Physiology
  • Communications

Students also learn and develop academic skills that are needed to effectively engage with the content of the medical program.

The program focuses on two broad topic areas in Basic and Clinical Sciences and Academic Skills.  Students are introduced to the Basic and Clinical Sciences covered in first year medicine.  These will include:

The Indigenous Pre-Social Work course is designed for Indigenous students wanting to enter the Bachelor of Social Work or any of the combined Social Work degrees. Students will undertake a variety of seminars and activities designed to assist them to prepare for entry into social work and to develop an understanding of the social work course and the social work profession.

Students will undertake a variety of seminars and activities designed to assist them to prepare for entry into social work and to develop an understanding of the social work course and the social work profession.

The Pre-Teacher Education Program is an academic preparatory and enabling program designed for Indigenous students to undertake further undergraduate degree studies in education for the pupose of becoming secondary school teachers. The program focuses on the following topics:


  • an introduction to teaching
  • academic literacy and classroom interaction
  • how students learn
  • the social context of schooling
  • Indigenous perspectives in education

contentlets.description:
The Pre-Teacher Education Program is an academic preparatory and enabling program designed for Indigenous students to undertake further undergraduate degree studies in education for the pupose of becoming secondary school teachers. The program focuses on the following topics:

  • an introduction to teaching
  • academic literacy and classroom interaction
  • how students learn
  • the social context of schooling
  • Indigenous perspectives in education
contentlets.title: Pre-Teacher Education Program (Secondary) (Indigenous)

Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ATSI7007 - Pre-Science and Engineering Program (Indigenous)","description":"

The Indigenous Pre-Science/Engineering course is an intensive four-week residential course for prospective Indigenous students wanting to enrol in an undergraduate degree in the faculties of Science or Engineering at UNSW. The course has been designed to assess your academic potential and to provide a realistic environment within which you can develop the knowledge and skills to manage your undergraduate studies effectively.


The Pre-Science/Engineering course will engage you in learning activities associated with the following disciplines: Mathematics, Chemistry, Biology, Psychology, Sustainable Engineering, Computer Science.  There is a strong focus on the acquisition of the study and learning skills required to undertake studies at the university level. Students are also given opportunities to apply their learning through fieldwork, written and oral presentations.


Entry into the Indigenous Pre-Science/Engineering course would require students to apply through Nura Gili. Students would have to:


  • Attach documentation to confirm their Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander descent as part of the application process.
  • Lodge an application with the Universities Admissions Centre (UAC) for the UNSW undergraduate degree program that they wish to study
  • Complete the online Nura Gili, UNSW Indigenous Preparatory Programs application and attach all supporting documentation.

On successful completion of the course, measured through participation, assessments and a final interview, students may then be offered a place in a relevant degree at UNSW. For further information please contact Nura Gili at UNSW.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"7d38585bdb25f450be4672f5f396195c","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Attendance","value":"attendance"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"10","description":"

Students will be evaluated on their engagement, participation and motivation throughout the program including their engagement in class work, group work and field work. Students will have an opportunity to discuss participation feedback with staff during their exit interview. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"b138585bdb25f450be4672f5f3961960","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"b138585bdb25f450be4672f5f3961962","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"b938585bdb25f450be4672f5f396195e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0638585bdb25f450be4672f5f396196f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Oral Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

Students will be asked to give a short oral presentation on a key learning from the program in front of teaching staff and other course participants. This oral presentation is modelled after the 3-minute thesis pitches that are increasingly common in STEM disciplines and test both communication and synthesis skills. Students will be given on the spot feedback as well as feedback during their exit interview. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO9","cl_id":"b938585bdb25f450be4672f5f396195e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO11","cl_id":"b938585bdb25f450be4672f5f3961960","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8a38585bdb25f450be4672f5f396196b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reflective Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Students will be asked to complete a reflective activity at the beginning of the program considering their interest in the topic area, their sense of preparedness for a university degree and personal motivation and commitment. They will be asked to complete a second reflective activity at the end of the program where they can consider their growth, challenges and successes throughout the program. Students will be given oral feedback on this assessment during their exit interview. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO10","cl_id":"b138585bdb25f450be4672f5f396195f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b538585bdb25f450be4672f5f3961964","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Lab Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Students will need to complete a lab report according to the process and guidelines taught to them in their Learning Skills course. Students can complete this lab report on any of the lab activities undertaken throughout the program. Students will be given oral feedback on this lab report during their exit interview. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"b138585bdb25f450be4672f5f396195e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"b938585bdb25f450be4672f5f3961961","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"b938585bdb25f450be4672f5f3961962","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bd38585bdb25f450be4672f5f3961966","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"50","description":"

At the end of the preparatory program, students will sit an extensive examination which will cover much of the course content covered throughout the program. This exam will have a high focus on mathematical skills. Exam conditions and format will emulate first-year exams and will include multiple choice, short answer, mathematical problems and longer form questions. Students will not receive their final grades on the exam but key areas of success and challenge will be highlighted during the exit interview and students will be given recommendations as to how they can improve weaker skill areas.
